description: Frameworks for understanding human psychological patterns, cognitive biases, and emotional responses to help Theta develop deeper psychological reasoning.

frameworks.name: Cognitive Dissonance
frameworks.core_concept: Psychological tension that occurs when beliefs conflict with behavior

theoretical_origins.original_context: Study of a doomsday cult whose prophecy failed but members subsequently became more committed

psychological_mechanisms: Selective information seeking that confirms existing beliefs

real_world_examples.scenario: A person who believes in environmental protection but drives a gas-guzzling vehicle
real_world_examples.internal_experience: Discomfort leading to either rationalization ('I need this car for my job') or behavior change (buying a more efficient vehicle)
real_world_examples.resolution_patterns: Changing beliefs ('Environmental impact of individual choices is minimal'), changing behavior (buying electric vehicle), or adding new justifying cognitions ('I offset my carbon footprint in other ways')

real_world_examples.scenario: Smoker who continues despite knowing health risks
real_world_examples.internal_experience: Anxiety about contradiction between knowledge and behavior
real_world_examples.resolution_patterns: Downplaying risks ('My grandfather smoked and lived to 95'), emphasizing short-term benefits ('It helps me manage stress'), adding compensatory behaviors ('I exercise regularly')

real_world_examples.scenario: Purchasing an expensive item that turns out to be disappointing
real_world_examples.internal_experience: Conflict between expectation and reality causing psychological discomfort
real_world_examples.resolution_patterns: Focusing on positive aspects, downplaying negative features, seeking confirming opinions from others, rejecting contradictory information

experimental_evidence.methodology: Participants rate items, choose between similarly rated items, then re-rate all items
experimental_evidence.findings: After choice, chosen items rated higher and rejected items rated lower than initial ratings
experimental_evidence.significance: Demonstrates post-decision attitude change to reduce dissonance about potentially making wrong choice

experimental_evidence.methodology: Participants paid either $1 or $20 to tell next participant that boring task was interesting
experimental_evidence.findings: $1 group rated task as more interesting than $20 group
experimental_evidence.significance: Insufficient external justification ($1) led to internal attitude change to justify behavior

neurological_correlates.activation_patterns: Increased anterior cingulate activity during cognitive conflict, followed by prefrontal activation during dissonance resolution
neurological_correlates.physiological_markers: Increased skin conductance, elevated cortisol levels during dissonance states

personality_factors.effect: Greater discomfort from dissonance, more rapid resolution attempts
Less dissonance when behavior inconsistent with attitudes but aligned with social context
Collectivist cultures experience greater dissonance for group-relevant contradictions than individual ones

applications.therapy: Motivational interviewing highlights dissonance between values and addictive behaviors to encourage change
applications.marketing: Free trials create ownership feelings that increase purchase likelihood to reduce dissonance
applications.environmental_advocacy: Highlighting inconsistency between pro-environmental values and high-impact behaviors

related_theories.name: Self-perception theory
related_theories.relationship: Alternative explanation suggesting people infer attitudes from observing their own behavior

related_theories.name: Balance theory
related_theories.relationship: Similar focus on psychological consistency but emphasizes triadic relationships

frameworks.name: Confirmation Bias
frameworks.core_concept: Tendency to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information that confirms pre-existing beliefs

theoretical_origins.original_context: Logical reasoning tasks showing people preferentially tested hypotheses by confirming rather than falsifying

psychological_mechanisms: Selective exposure to information aligning with existing views
Motivated reasoning to reach desired conclusions

real_world_examples.manifestation: Seeking information from sources aligned with political orientation
real_world_examples.consequences: Increasing polarization, decreased ability to understand opposing viewpoints
real_world_examples.mitigation_strategies: Deliberately seeking diverse news sources, engaging with thoughtful opposing opinions

real_world_examples.manifestation: Physician focuses on evidence supporting initial diagnosis while downplaying contradictory symptoms
real_world_examples.mitigation_strategies: Differential diagnosis protocols, second opinions, diagnostic checklists

real_world_examples.manifestation: Manager notices employee behaviors that confirm initial impression, overlooks contradictory evidence
real_world_examples.mitigation_strategies: Structured evaluation criteria, multiple evaluators, awareness training

experimental_evidence.methodology: Participants asked to test a conditional rule by selecting cards to turn over
experimental_evidence.findings: Most select cards that could confirm the rule, not those that could falsify it
experimental_evidence.significance: Demonstrated fundamental flaw in human hypothesis testing

experimental_evidence.methodology: Participants with opposing views on capital punishment evaluated same studies
experimental_evidence.findings: Both groups found studies supporting their position more convincing, became more polarized after exposure to mixed evidence
experimental_evidence.significance: Showed biased assimilation of identical information based on prior beliefs

neurological_correlates.activation_patterns: Reduced activity in anterior cingulate when processing counterattitudinal information, increased amygdala activation to threatening belief-inconsistent information
neurological_correlates.physiological_markers: Increased heart rate when processing strongly contradictory information

personality_factors.effect: Higher need associated with stronger confirmation bias
Higher reflective thinking associated with reduced bias
More dogmatic individuals show stronger confirmation bias effects

applications.scientific_method: Procedures for hypothesis falsification and peer review designed to counter confirmation bias
applications.judicial_systems: Adversarial process ensures evidence both supporting and contradicting charges is presented
applications.business: Devil's advocate roles and pre-mortem exercises to counteract groupthink and confirmation bias

related_theories.name: Cognitive dissonance
related_theories.relationship: Confirmation bias helps prevent dissonance by avoiding contradictory information

related_theories.name: Motivated reasoning
related_theories.relationship: Confirmation bias is one mechanism through which motivated reasoning operates

related_theories.name: Belief perseverance
related_theories.relationship: Confirmation bias contributes to persistence of beliefs despite contradictory evidence

frameworks.name: System 1 and System 2 Thinking
frameworks.core_concept: Dual-process theory distinguishing between fast, intuitive cognitive processes (System 1) and slow, deliberative processes (System 2)

theoretical_origins.original_context: Research on judgment and decision-making biases and heuristics

examples: Looking for specific person in crowd

interaction_patterns.description: System 2 generally accepts System 1 impressions without scrutiny unless difficulty detected
interaction_patterns.example: Accepting initial impression of a person's trustworthiness without questioning evidence

interaction_patterns.description: System 2 can override System 1 when errors detected or deliberation needed
interaction_patterns.example: Catching oneself before making inappropriate comment suggested by automatic association

interaction_patterns.description: When System 2 is busy or depleted, System 1 exerts greater influence on behavior
interaction_patterns.example: Making impulsive food choices when mentally fatigued

real_world_examples.System 1 response: Grabbing familiar brands automatically, responding to colorful packaging
real_world_examples.System 2 response: Comparing nutritional information, calculating price per unit, planning meals
real_world_examples.interaction: System 1 drives most routine purchases while System 2 engages for new products or conscious health decisions

real_world_examples.System 1 response: Immediate emotional reaction based on sender and initial impression of request
real_world_examples.System 2 response: Analyzing implications, considering alternatives, drafting careful response
real_world_examples.interaction: Initial reaction shapes emotional tone while deliberative process determines actual response

real_world_examples.System 1 response: Immediate threat assessment, physiological arousal, intuitive action impulses
real_world_examples.System 2 response: Evaluating options, recalling training, anticipating consequences
real_world_examples.interaction: System 1 provides rapid response while System 2 refines action when time permits

experimental_evidence.methodology: Problems with intuitive but wrong answers requiring deliberation to solve correctly
experimental_evidence.findings: Many participants give intuitive System 1 answers without engaging System 2 verification
experimental_evidence.example_problem: A bat and ball cost $1.10. The bat costs $1.00 more than the ball. How much does the ball cost? (Intuitive answer: 10 cents; correct answer: 5 cents)

experimental_evidence.methodology: Naming ink colors of color words that either match or conflict with the word
experimental_evidence.findings: Slower responses when word and color conflict due to System 2 overriding automatic word reading
experimental_evidence.significance: Demonstrates competition between automatic and controlled processes

cognitive_biases_explained.mechanism: System 1 uses initial value as reference point; System 2 fails to adjust sufficiently
cognitive_biases_explained.example: Initial house price affecting perceived value even if arbitrary

cognitive_biases_explained.mechanism: System 1 judges probability by ease of recall; System 2 fails to correct for sample bias
cognitive_biases_explained.example: Overestimating crime rates after exposure to crime news

cognitive_biases_explained.mechanism: System 1 answers easier question than one asked; System 2 doesn't detect substitution
cognitive_biases_explained.example: Judging political candidate on likability rather than policy positions

practical_applications.education: Teaching metacognitive strategies to engage System 2 when appropriate
practical_applications.marketing: Creating intuitive, emotional appeals for System 1 while providing logical justifications for System 2
practical_applications.decision_making: Creating environments and procedures that activate System 2 for important decisions
practical_applications.design: Creating interfaces that work with natural System 1 processes rather than against them

criticisms.explanation: Actual cognitive processes involve spectrum rather than two distinct systems
criticisms.counterpoint: Useful as conceptual model even if biological reality is more complex

criticisms.explanation: Theory may overvalue Western analytical thinking (System 2) over intuitive knowledge
criticisms.counterpoint: Research shows universal cognitive biases despite cultural differences

frameworks.name: Attachment Theory
frameworks.core_concept: Framework describing how early relationships with caregivers create internal working models that influence relationships throughout life

theoretical_origins.founder: John Bowlby, expanded by Mary Ainsworth
theoretical_origins.original_context: Observation of children's responses to separation from caregivers

attachment_styles.childhood_manifestation: Distress when caregiver leaves, easily comforted upon return, uses caregiver as secure base for exploration
attachment_styles.adult_manifestation: Comfortable with intimacy and autonomy, effective communication during conflict, appropriate trust
attachment_styles.formation_factors: Consistent, responsive caregiving in early childhood

attachment_styles.childhood_manifestation: Intense distress at separation, difficult to comfort upon reunion, reduced exploration
attachment_styles.adult_manifestation: Fears abandonment, seeks excessive reassurance, hypervigilant to relationship threats
attachment_styles.formation_factors: Inconsistent caregiving - sometimes attentive, sometimes neglectful

attachment_styles.childhood_manifestation: Minimal visible distress at separation, avoids caregiver upon reunion, independent play
attachment_styles.adult_manifestation: Discomfort with closeness, high self-reliance, difficulty expressing emotions

attachment_styles.childhood_manifestation: Contradictory behaviors, freezing, confusion during separations and reunions
attachment_styles.adult_manifestation: Chaotic relationships, fear of both intimacy and abandonment, difficulty regulating emotions
attachment_styles.formation_factors: Frightening or abusive caregiving, caregiver with unresolved trauma
attachment_styles.estimated_prevalence: 5-10% in general population, higher in clinical populations

developmental_trajectory.infancy: Formation of attachment to primary caregivers through physical contact and emotional attunement
developmental_trajectory.early_childhood: Development of internal working models based on caregiver responsiveness
developmental_trajectory.middle_childhood: Expansion of attachment network to include peers and other adults
developmental_trajectory.adolescence: Transfer of attachment functions from parents to peers and romantic partners
developmental_trajectory.adulthood: Attachment patterns influence romantic relationships, friendships, and parenting

neurobiological_foundations.mechanisms: Early caregiving experiences shape neural development through stress response regulation, reward system activation, and interoceptive awareness
neurobiological_foundations.epigenetic_effects: Animal studies demonstrate intergenerational transmission of attachment patterns through epigenetic modifications

relationship_dynamics.secure_pattern: Healthy pace of intimacy development, balanced self-disclosure
relationship_dynamics.avoidant_pattern: Maintaining emotional distance, discomfort with partner's vulnerability
relationship_dynamics.disorganized_pattern: Chaotic approach-avoidance behaviors, intensity followed by withdrawal

relationship_dynamics.secure_pattern: Collaborative problem-solving, repair attempts, effective emotion regulation
relationship_dynamics.anxious_pattern: Emotional escalation, pursuit behaviors, difficulty self-soothing
relationship_dynamics.avoidant_pattern: Withdrawal, minimization of issues, emotional shutdown
relationship_dynamics.disorganized_pattern: Alternating hostility and helplessness, difficulty maintaining focus on issue

relationship_dynamics.secure_pattern: Responsive support without taking over problem-solving
relationship_dynamics.anxious_pattern: Over-involvement, may amplify partner's distress through emotional contagion
relationship_dynamics.avoidant_pattern: Practical support without emotional engagement, discomfort with partner's vulnerability
relationship_dynamics.disorganized_pattern: Inconsistent support, may be triggered by partner's vulnerability

clinical_applications.psychotherapy: Emotionally Focused Therapy uses attachment framework to identify and transform negative interaction cycles
clinical_applications.parenting_interventions: Circle of Security program helps caregivers respond sensitively to attachment needs
clinical_applications.trauma_treatment: Understanding disorganized attachment crucial for treating complex trauma histories
clinical_applications.grief_counseling: Attachment perspective helps understand variation in grief responses

stability_and_change.continuity_factors: Early patterns tend to persist in absence of significant corrective experiences
change_mechanisms: Significant romantic relationships with secure partners
Conscious reflection and integration of attachment history
Development of earned security through processing childhood experiences
stability_and_change.research_findings: Approximately 30% of individuals show attachment style changes in adulthood

cross-cultural_considerations.universal_aspects: Secure base phenomenon observed across cultures

cultural_variations.difference: Greater emphasis on family interdependence versus individual autonomy
Multiple attachment figures more common in some cultures versus Western nuclear family model

cross-cultural_considerations.methodological_challenges: Assessment tools developed in Western contexts may not capture cultural variations in attachment manifestations

frameworks.name: Cognitive Behavioral Framework
frameworks.core_concept: Interconnection between thoughts, emotions, behaviors, and physiological responses, with thoughts playing central role in psychological functioning

key_publications: A New Guide to Rational Living
theoretical_origins.original_context: Alternative to psychoanalytic approaches, focusing on present thought patterns

fundamental_principles.explanation: How we interpret events determines emotional responses, not events themselves
fundamental_principles.example: Two people experience job loss: one catastrophizes ('My career is over'), while another sees opportunity ('I can now find better work')

fundamental_principles.explanation: Underlying belief structures that organize information and guide processing
fundamental_principles.example: Core belief 'I'm unlovable' filters perception to notice rejection and discount acceptance

fundamental_principles.explanation: Systematic errors in thinking that maintain negative emotions

common_types.example: After minor mistake at work: 'I'll definitely be fired'

common_types.definition: Viewing situations in extreme, binary categories
common_types.example: Either my presentation is perfect, or I'm a complete failure

common_types.definition: Assuming you know what others are thinking without evidence
common_types.example: They didn't smile, so they must think I'm boring

common_types.definition: Taking emotions as evidence of truth
common_types.example: I feel inadequate, therefore I must be inadequate

fundamental_principles.explanation: Thoughts, emotions, behaviors, and physical reactions mutually influence each other
fundamental_principles.example: Anxious thoughts → physical tension → avoidance behavior → reinforced anxious thoughts

cognitive_behavioral_process.beliefs: Interpretations, appraisals, and thoughts about the event

consequences.behavioral: Actions taken based on beliefs and feelings
consequences.physiological: Physical responses activated by beliefs and emotions

example_sequence.situation: Email from boss saying 'We need to talk tomorrow'
example_sequence.automatic_thought: I must have made a serious mistake, I'm going to be fired
example_sequence.behavior: Checking work frantically, difficulty sleeping, avoiding colleagues
example_sequence.physical: Increased heart rate, muscle tension, stomach discomfort

example_sequence.alternative_thought: The boss might want to discuss a new project or give feedback
example_sequence.resulting_behavior: Preparing for meeting calmly, normal sleep pattern

common_intervention_strategies.process: Identifying, evaluating, and modifying unhelpful thoughts
steps: Identify automatic thoughts during emotional distress
Evaluate evidence supporting and contradicting thought
Practice applying balanced thinking to similar situations
common_intervention_strategies.clinical_example: Depression client challenging thought 'Nobody cares about me' by listing evidence of others showing care

steps: Compare results to prediction and update beliefs
common_intervention_strategies.clinical_example: Social anxiety client who believes 'People will notice if I blush' deliberately applying makeup to look flushed in social setting

common_intervention_strategies.process: Systematic confrontation of feared situations without avoidance
steps: Remain in situation until anxiety decreases
common_intervention_strategies.clinical_example: Panic disorder client gradually practicing situations that trigger panic symptoms

common_intervention_strategies.process: Planning rewarding and mastery activities to counter behavioral withdrawal
steps: Identify activities that provide pleasure or sense of accomplishment
Rate mood before and after to demonstrate connection
common_intervention_strategies.clinical_example: Depression client scheduling daily walk despite lack of motivation, experiencing mood improvement

empirical_support.meta_analytic_findings: Strong evidence for effectiveness across multiple disorders including depression, anxiety disorders, PTSD, and eating disorders
empirical_support.comparative_effectiveness: Generally equivalent to medication for depression, superior for preventing relapse
empirical_support.neurobiological_effects: Documented changes in brain activity patterns similar to medication effects
empirical_support.limitations: Less effective for schizophrenia as standalone treatment, bipolar disorder requires medication integration

contemporary_developments.key_difference: Focus on accepting thoughts rather than changing them, values-based behavior change
contemporary_developments.core_processes: Cognitive defusion, mindfulness, commitment to valued action

contemporary_developments.key_difference: Balances acceptance and change, emphasizes emotion regulation and interpersonal effectiveness
contemporary_developments.core_processes: Mindfulness, distress tolerance, emotion regulation, interpersonal effectiveness

contemporary_developments.key_difference: Incorporates meditation practices, focus on relationship to thoughts rather than content
contemporary_developments.core_processes: Mindfulness of breath and body, thoughts as mental events rather than facts

applications_beyond_therapy.organizational: Stress management programs, leadership development focusing on thinking patterns
applications_beyond_therapy.educational: Growth mindset interventions, resilience training for students
applications_beyond_therapy.sports: Performance enhancement through managing self-talk and cognitive appraisal
applications_beyond_therapy.public_health: Scalable digital interventions based on CBT principles for population mental health

frameworks.name: Social Identity Theory
frameworks.core_concept: People's sense of who they are is based on their group memberships and these social identities shape intergroup behavior

theoretical_origins.key_publication: An Integrative Theory of Intergroup Conflict (1979)
theoretical_origins.original_context: Post-World War II attempt to understand prejudice, discrimination, and intergroup conflict

central_concepts.explanation: Cognitive process of grouping people (including oneself) into social categories
central_concepts.application: People classify themselves and others as members of various groups: nationality, religion, gender, occupation, etc.
central_concepts.example: Perceiving oneself primarily as 'a teacher' in professional contexts, affecting behavior and self-perception

central_concepts.explanation: Emotional significance attached to group memberships that becomes part of self-concept
central_concepts.application: Adopting attitudes, perspectives, and behaviors seen as normative for the group
central_concepts.example: Sports team supporters feeling personal elation or despair based on team performance

central_concepts.explanation: Evaluating one's groups in comparison with others to maintain positive distinctiveness
central_concepts.application: Seeking ways to view one's ingroups as better than relevant outgroups
central_concepts.example: Highlighting achievements of one's university while downplaying those of rival institutions

central_concepts.explanation: Even arbitrary, minimal basis for group categorization can trigger ingroup favoritism
central_concepts.application: People favor their group even when groups are formed on trivial or random criteria
central_concepts.example: Experimental participants favoring others assigned to same group based on supposed 'dot estimation ability'

intergroup_phenomena.description: Tendency to favor members of one's own group over outgroup members
manifestations: Resource allocation biased toward ingroup members
More positive evaluations of ingroup products and performances
Greater cooperation with and trust of ingroup members
Attributional biases favoring ingroup (success due to ability, failure to circumstances)

intergroup_phenomena.description: Perception that outgroup members are more similar to each other than ingroup members
manifestations: Reduced recognition of individual differences within outgroups
More nuanced perception of ingroup diversity

intergroup_phenomena.description: Competition between groups even when no objective conflict of interest exists
manifestations: Zero-sum thinking about status and resources
Status competition through distinct group dimensions

identity_management_strategies.description: Individual attempts to leave or dissociate from devalued group
identity_management_strategies.examples: Career advancement to higher status, assimilation to dominant culture, 'passing'
identity_management_strategies.psychological_implications: Identity conflict, potential rejection from both groups, internalized stigma

identity_management_strategies.description: Redefining elements of comparative situation to enhance ingroup's position
identity_management_strategies.conditions: Impermeable group boundaries, stable status hierarchy
examples: Comparing on new dimensions ('we may be poorer but we're happier')
Revaluing previously negative characteristics ('Black is beautiful')
Changing comparison outgroup (comparing with equally or more disadvantaged groups)
identity_management_strategies.psychological_implications: Enhanced group esteem without structural change, potential for positive reappraisal

identity_management_strategies.description: Direct challenge to existing status hierarchy through collective action
identity_management_strategies.conditions: Impermeable boundaries, unstable/illegitimate status differences, cognitive alternatives
identity_management_strategies.examples: Political movements, protests, revolutions, labor strikes
identity_management_strategies.psychological_implications: Heightened group identification, increased intergroup polarization

applications.organizational_psychology: Understanding mergers, organizational identification, workplace diversity dynamics
applications.political_psychology: Partisan identification, nationalism, political polarization processes
applications.marketing: Brand communities, identity-based marketing, consumer loyalty development
applications.education: School belonging, stereotype threat mitigation, inclusive classroom practices

contemporary_developments.contribution: Elaborates cognitive processes of social categorization and contextual factors affecting salience
Explains how rejection by outgroups can increase identification with one's ingroup
Examines how people manage and integrate various group memberships

frameworks.name: Transtheoretical Model of Behavior Change
frameworks.core_concept: Behavior change occurs through a sequence of stages with different processes effective at each stage

theoretical_origins.key_publication: Transtheoretical therapy: Toward a more integrative model of change (1982)
theoretical_origins.original_context: Studying how people quit smoking without formal intervention programs

characteristics: No intention to change behavior in foreseeable future (typically next 6 months)
May be unaware of problem or have given up after failed attempts
Often defensive about behavior when confronted
May see more costs than benefits to change
stages_of_change.experiential_markers: 'I don't have a problem,' 'People are overreacting about my behavior'
intervention_approaches: Raise awareness about risks without confrontation
Provide personalized feedback about impact
Encourage self-reevaluation
Express empathy without judgment

characteristics: Aware of problem and seriously considering action within next 6 months
Ambivalent about change - weighing pros and cons
May remain stuck for extended periods ('chronic contemplation')
Seeking information about possible solutions
stages_of_change.experiential_markers: 'I know I should change, but...', 'I'm thinking about making changes soon'
intervention_approaches: Explore ambivalence through decisional balance exercises
Build confidence in ability to change
Examine values alignment with behavior change
Discuss previous change attempts constructively

characteristics: Intending to take action in immediate future (usually within one month)
May have already taken small steps toward change
Developing concrete plans for action
Announcing intentions to others
stages_of_change.experiential_markers: 'I've started cutting back,' 'I've signed up for a program that starts next week'
intervention_approaches: Help develop concrete action plans with specific steps
Problem-solve anticipated obstacles
Identify social support resources
Enhance commitment through public declarations

characteristics: Actively modifying behavior, experiences, or environment for 1 day to 6 months
Observable changes requiring considerable commitment
Implementing specific change strategies
High risk of relapse
stages_of_change.experiential_markers: 'I'm working hard at changing,' 'I've been [new behavior] for three weeks now'
intervention_approaches: Provide reinforcement for progress
Teach stimulus control techniques
Help restructure environment to support change
Develop effective coping strategies for high-risk situations

characteristics: Working to prevent relapse and consolidate gains for 6+ months after initial action
Decreased temptation and increased confidence
Integrating new behavior into lifestyle
Remaining vigilant about high-risk situations
stages_of_change.experiential_markers: 'This is becoming part of who I am,' 'I have strategies for handling difficult situations'
intervention_approaches: Plan for coping with unexpected triggers or setbacks
Develop alternative behaviors for meeting needs previously met by problem behavior
Foster identity shift incorporating new behavior pattern
Build lifestyle balance to reduce need for problem behavior

change_processes.description: Internal cognitive and emotional activities that facilitate change

processes.definition: Increasing awareness about problem behavior and potential solutions
processes.techniques: Education, feedback, confrontation, interpretation, media campaigns

processes.definition: Experiencing and expressing feelings about the problem and solutions
processes.techniques: Role-playing, grieving losses, personal testimonials, media campaigns

processes.definition: Assessing how problem behavior affects social environment
processes.techniques: Empathy training, family interventions, documentary videos

processes.definition: Reassessing values and self-image related to problem behavior
processes.techniques: Value clarification, imagery, corrective emotional experiences

processes.definition: Increasing awareness of social alternatives and opportunities

change_processes.description: External activities and strategies that modify behavior and environment

processes.definition: Substituting healthier behaviors and thoughts for problem behavior
Using social support for change efforts
processes.techniques: Therapeutic alliance, social support, self-help groups, buddy systems
Contingency contracts, overt and covert reinforcement, self-reward

processes.definition: Choosing and committing to act or belief in ability to change
processes.techniques: New Year's resolutions, commitment enhancing techniques, public testimonies

processes.definition: Removing cues for unhealthy habits, adding prompts for healthy alternatives

applications.health_behaviors: Smoking cessation, exercise adoption, dietary change, medication adherence
applications.addiction_treatment: Substance abuse interventions, gambling addiction, process addictions
applications.psychotherapy: Treatment planning, intervention selection, relapse prevention
applications.health_promotion: Public health campaigns, preventative interventions, screening participation

decisional_balance.concept: Weighing perceived pros and cons of behavior change
stage_patterns: Precontemplation: Cons of changing outweigh pros
Contemplation: Pros and cons nearly equal
decisional_balance.significance: Critical concept for understanding and facilitating stage transitions

self-efficacy.concept: Confidence in ability to cope with high-risk situations without relapsing
self-efficacy.development: Increases as person moves through stages of change
self-efficacy.intervention_implications: Identifying high-risk situations and building coping strategies enhances self-efficacy

strengths: Validated across numerous health behaviors and populations
Practical framework for matching interventions to readiness
Acknowledges change as process rather than event
limitations: Debate about discrete vs. continuous nature of stages
Questions about arbitrary time frames defining stages
Mixed results for stage-matched vs. action-oriented interventions
Simplified representation of complex change processes

frameworks.name: Self-Determination Theory
frameworks.core_concept: Psychological well-being and optimal functioning depend on satisfying basic psychological needs for autonomy, competence, and relatedness

theoretical_origins.key_publication: Intrinsic Motivation and Self-Determination in Human Behavior (1985)
theoretical_origins.original_context: Research on intrinsic vs. extrinsic motivation and their differential effects

basic_psychological_needs.definition: Sense of volition and willingness; feeling like originator of one's actions
supportive_conditions: Providing meaningful rationales for requested behavior
Acknowledging negative feelings about difficult tasks
thwarting_conditions: External rewards for intrinsically motivated activities
basic_psychological_needs.developmental_significance: Crucial for internalization of values and regulations

basic_psychological_needs.definition: Feeling effective in interactions with environment; experiencing mastery and growth
supportive_conditions: Strategies and tools for overcoming obstacles
thwarting_conditions: Overly difficult or trivially easy tasks
Negative feedback focusing on personal failings
Impossible standards or constantly changing expectations
basic_psychological_needs.developmental_significance: Drives exploration and mastery attempts from infancy onward

basic_psychological_needs.definition: Feeling connected to and cared for by others; sense of belonging
supportive_conditions: Genuine interest and empathy from others
basic_psychological_needs.developmental_significance: Provides secure base for exploration and internalization of social values

motivation_continuum.quality: Complete lack of intentionality and motivation
motivation_continuum.example: Student who sees no value in schoolwork and makes no effort
Working solely to earn money or avoid punishment
Studying to avoid guilt or maintain self-worth
Exercising because one values health benefits
Professional development aligned with core values and identity
Pursuing hobby for pure enjoyment of activity itself

key_propositions: External events affect intrinsic motivation through perceived autonomy and competence
Rewards, feedback, and other external events have both controlling and informational aspects
Controlling aspects decrease autonomy and intrinsic motivation
Informational aspects support competence and enhance intrinsic motivation

mini-theories.focus: Process of internalization and integration of extrinsic motivation
key_propositions: Humans naturally internalize and integrate socially valued regulations
Internalization varies along continuum from external to integrated regulation
Need support facilitates internalization and integration
More integrated forms of regulation associated with greater well-being and performance
Autonomy orientation: Focus on interest, values, and self-determined regulation
Control orientation: Focus on rewards, gains, approvals, and controls
Impersonal orientation: Focus on obstacles and amotivation
People vary in strength of these orientations, affecting interpretation of events

mini-theories.focus: Relationship between need satisfaction and well-being
key_propositions: Autonomy, competence, and relatedness are universal psychological needs
Satisfaction of these needs essential for psychological growth and well-being
Environmental factors affecting need satisfaction impact development and functioning
Need frustration contributes to ill-being and psychopathology

mini-theories.focus: Differential effects of intrinsic versus extrinsic goals
key_propositions: Intrinsic goals (growth, relationships, community) directly satisfy basic needs
Extrinsic goals (wealth, fame, image) at best indirectly satisfy needs
Focus on intrinsic goals associated with greater well-being than extrinsic goals
Pursuit of extrinsic goals can detract from need satisfaction and well-being
High-quality relationships satisfy need for relatedness
Best relationships also support autonomy and competence
Mutual need support creates relationship synergy
Need frustration in relationships predicts relational and individual problems

principles: Supporting student autonomy improves engagement, learning, and persistence
Informational feedback enhances perceived competence and intrinsic motivation
Teacher-student relatedness increases internalization of educational values
education.interventions: Autonomy-supportive teaching, mastery-oriented assessment, classroom belonging

principles: Autonomy support improves treatment adherence and health outcomes
Need satisfaction facilitates health behavior change and maintenance
Controlling approaches to health promotion often backfire
healthcare.interventions: Motivational interviewing, patient-centered care, health coaching

principles: Need-supportive environments increase job satisfaction, performance, and retention
Autonomous motivation associated with greater creativity and well-being
Controlling management styles reduce productivity and increase turnover
workplace.interventions: Managerial training in autonomy support, meaningful work design, team cohesion

principles: Autonomy-supportive parenting facilitates internalization and adjustment
Conditional regard undermines relationship quality and internalization
parenting.interventions: Parent training in autonomy support, emotion coaching, positive discipline

cross-cultural_research.universality: Basic needs appear universal across cultures, though expression may vary

cultural_variations.collectivist_cultures: Autonomy expressed through endorsed interdependence, not independence
cultural_variations.vertical_hierarchies: Autonomy possible within hierarchies when values genuinely accepted

cross-cultural_research.findings: Need satisfaction predicts well-being across diverse cultural contexts
